results.title: Becoming me
results.creator_credit: Tyson Cunningham, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Tyson Cunningham can’t express himself, music does it for him. Although he has long given up dreams of fronting a band like his brother, music is still everything to him, and expresses his emotional life like nothing else.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tyson Cunningham, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: T Pyxidis
results.creator_credit: Melanie Steptoe, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Ride
results.creator_credit: Matthew Hunt, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Matt Hunt talks candidly about his all-consuming addiction: riding bikes. It is an obsession that has changed the way he looks at the world, cost him physically and financially but one that he is not likely to give up soon.

results.title: Family treasures
results.creator_credit: Penny Morison, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Penny Morison provides a sensorial experience as she recalls her many holidays spent at the family holiday home in Aireys Inlet, on the south-west coast of Victoria. Run by her aunt, the holiday home has provided countless Summer memories for Penny as she was growing up and for future generations.

results.title: Street kids
results.creator_credit: Dmitry Schukin, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: From Russia to Werribee, via the gangs of Los Angeles and Las Vegas, Dmitry Schukin’s story is one of redemption through art. He talks openly about the crimes of his past and the pursuits that have helped him channel all the negative into something positive and given Schukin something to fight for.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dmitry Schukin, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Just say no
results.creator_credit: Christiana Dumitru, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Christiana Dumitru’s father died and her family had to move, she turned to a partying lifestyle. Hooked on drugs at an alarmingly young age, Dumitru reflects on the strength of will she had to summon to get back on track and the friends and family she has learnt to value.

results.title: Life will never be the same
results.creator_credit: Amanda Jurisic, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: ‘You don’t need to jump on a plane, or go to a theme park or stay at a five star hotel to experience the beautiful things in life.’ Amanda Jurisic remembers her father’s legacy : a sense of adventure and a love of travel. The values he taught her have stayed with her, and inspired her to travel the world.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Amanda Jurisic, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Expectations
results.creator_credit: Jimmy Pasakos, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: In this initimate use of the form of Digital Storytelling, Jim Pasakos puts together this story for his child. Using second person narrative, Pasakos tells of the decision to have a baby and the processes leading up to the birth. This serves as a very personal account of childbirth and a cherished family record.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jimmy Pasakos, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: [District Nursing Appeal]
results.brief_description:
The Royal District Nursing Service was founded in 1885 and was originally called the Melbourne District Nursing Service. An initiative led by the Reverend Charles Strong, the organisation was established to nurse the sick, poor and disadvantaged in their own homes. By the early 1920s the nurses were treating 25,000 patients per year and had established a convalescent institution, the After-Care Home (later Hospital) in Collingwood. In 1966 the organisation became the Royal District Nursing Service.

In this television appeal from 1967, Graham Kennedy presents a feature on behalf of the Royal District Nursing Service. The film includes footage of Kennedy in the television studio, appealing for door knockers to help fundraise for the organisation. The program shows footage of Kennedy interviewing an elderly war veteran at his home in Albert Park, who lives alone and is visited by an RDNS nurse every day.

It appears this film was produced as a Kinescope - a 16mm film recording of a live television broadcast. As such, both the sound and image are a little ‘muddy’ as is typical of this technology.
results.description:
The Royal District Nursing Service was founded in 1885 and was originally called the Melbourne District Nursing Service. An initiative led by the Reverend Charles Strong, the organisation was established to nurse the sick, poor and disadvantaged in their own homes. By the early 1920s the nurses were treating 25,000 patients per year and had established a convalescent institution, the After-Care Home (later Hospital) in Collingwood. In 1966 the organisation became the Royal District Nursing Service.

In this television appeal from 1967, Graham Kennedy presents a feature on behalf of the Royal District Nursing Service. The film includes footage of Kennedy in the television studio, appealing for door knockers to help fundraise for the organisation. The program shows footage of Kennedy interviewing an elderly war veteran at his home in Albert Park, who lives alone and is visited by an RDNS nurse every day.

It appears this film was produced as a Kinescope - a 16mm film recording of a live television broadcast. As such, both the sound and image are a little ‘muddy’ as is typical of this technology.

The Royal District Nursing Service was founded in 1885 and was originally called the Melbourne District Nursing Service. An initiative led by the Reverend Charles Strong, the organisation was established to nurse the sick, poor and disadvantaged in their own homes. By the early 1920s the nurses were treating 25,000 patients per year and had established a convalescent institution, the After-Care Home (later Hospital) in Collingwood. In 1966 the organisation became the Royal District Nursing Service.

In this television appeal from 1967, Graham Kennedy presents a feature on behalf of the Royal District Nursing Service. The film includes footage of Kennedy in the television studio, appealing for door knockers to help fundraise for the organisation. The program shows footage of Kennedy interviewing an elderly war veteran at his home in Albert Park, who lives alone and is visited by an RDNS nurse every day.

It appears this film was produced as a Kinescope - a 16mm film recording of a live television broadcast. As such, both the sound and image are a little ‘muddy’ as is typical of this technology.
